front.title: YANG Model for Extensions to Network Instance

abstract.t: This document defines an extension to YANG Data Model for Network Instance (RFC8529). The extension includes a definition for Route Distinguisher.

section.title: Introduction
section.t: This document defines a YANG 1.1 data model to extend the YANG Data Model for Network Instance model. That extension includes a definition for Route Distinguisher (RD).
The YANG model defined in this document is Network Management Datastore Architecture compliant.

section.title: Motivation
section.t: Virtual Routing and Forwarding (VRF) allows IP address spaces to be reused among other isolated routing domains. A VRF is also referred to as a Network Instance (NI). By assigning each customer its own VRF the overlapping networks are kept isolated from one another.

This works well till such time the isolated networks have to communicate with the external world. To keep track of which route belongs to which VRF/customer, RDs are used. As the name implies, a RD distinguishes routes that belong to one VRF from routes that belong to another VRF. That is achieved by prepending a route with a unique number that belongs to a particular VRF or customer.
This model augments YANG Data Model for Network Instance to add the definition for RD.

section.title: Security Considerations
section.t: The YANG module specified in this document defines a schema for data that is designed to be accessed via network management protocols such as NETCONF or RESTCONF. The lowest NETCONF layer is the secure transport layer, and the mandatory-to-implement secure transport is Secure Shell (SSH). The lowest RESTCONF layer is HTTPS, and the mandatory-to-implement secure transport is TLS. The NETCONF Access Control Model (NACM) provides the means to restrict access for particular NETCONF or RESTCONF users to a preconfigured subset of all available NETCONF or RESTCONF protocol operations and content.

There are a number of data nodes defined in this YANG module that are writable/creatable/deletable (i.e., config true, which is the default). These data nodes may be considered sensitive or vulnerable in some network environments. Write operations (e.g., edit-config) to these data nodes without proper protection can have a negative effect on network operations. Some of the subtrees and data nodes and their sensitivity/vulnerability are described here.

ul.li: The attribute 'rd'. If a user is allowed to change this attribute, it will have the net effect of redirecting routes to the incorrect VRF or overriding a correctly learnt route.
